title: 109_s1916
content: The Act may be cited as the "Strengthening America's Security Act of 2005" and includes a table of contents. The "Strengthening America's Security Act of 2005" includes provisions for border enforcement studies, necessary assets for controlling US borders, document fraud detection, biometric entry-exit system, expedited removal between ports of entry, cancellation of visas, detention space, criminal penalties for alien smuggling, and removal of aliens. It also addresses increasing immigration personnel, automated alien records, Federal detention space, State Criminal Alien Assistance Program, and construction. The "Strengthening America's Security Act of 2005" includes provisions for border enforcement studies, assets for controlling US borders, document fraud detection, biometric entry-exit system, expedited removal, cancellation of visas, detention space, criminal penalties for alien smuggling, and removal of aliens. A study on preventing illegal entry through subterranean tunnels and barriers for land crossings is required by the Secretary of Homeland Security and the United States Army Corps of Engineers. The "Strengthening America's Security Act of 2005" mandates a study on the feasibility and effectiveness of primary and secondary fences along the US-Mexico border for security purposes. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit the study results to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. NECESSARY ASSETS FOR CONTROLLING UNITED STATES BORDERS. In fiscal years 2006 through 2010, the Secretary of Homeland Security must increase the number of full-time active duty Customs and Border Protection officers by at least 250 positions. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose as well as for Border Patrol agents. In fiscal years 2006 through 2010, the Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to procure technological assets such as unmanned aerial vehicles and sensors for border control. Appropriations are also authorized for the transportation of aliens and the construction of border control facilities. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct roads, acquire barriers, and facilities to achieve operational control of US borders. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2006-2010. Border Patrol checkpoints can be maintained within 100 miles of the US-Mexico border. SEC. 4. DOCUMENT FRAUD DETECTION. The Secretary of Homeland Security will provide training for customs and border protection officers in identifying fraudulent travel documents, in consultation with the Forensic Document Laboratory. Officers will have access to the Laboratory, and reports on its accuracy in detecting fraudulent documents will be submitted annually to the Office of the Inspector General. The Office of Inspector General will assess the accuracy of the Forensic Document Library and report to Congress. The Fraud Appellate Review Board within Immigration and Customs Enforcement will review determinations of document fraud, allowing aliens to appeal negative determinations. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums are authorized for fiscal years 2006 through 2010 to support the independent determination process by the Fraud Appellate Review Board. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report to Congress by October 26, 2007, detailing the need for machine-readable, tamper-resistant documents with biometric identifiers, how they will meet standards, locations for document readers, costs, and deadlines. Additionally, there is a provision for a biometric entry-exit system. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include grounds of inadmissibility for aliens who fail to comply with biometric data requests. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to determine inadmissibility and waive the application of this provision. Additionally, there is a requirement for the collection of biometric data from aliens departing the United States. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to collect biometric data from aliens departing the United States and applicants for admission or transit through the country. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to authorize the collection of biometric data from alien crewmen seeking temporary permission to land in the United States. Additionally, the 9/11 Commission Implementation Act of 2004 is amended to provide funding for implementing biometric data collection at all land border ports of entry. Authorized funding for implementing automated biometric entry and exit data system at all land border ports of entry for fiscal years 2006 and 2007. SEC. 7. EXPEDITED REMOVAL BETWEEN PORTS OF ENTRY. The amendment to Section 235 of the Immigration and Nationality Act expands expedited removal procedures to all border patrol sectors on the southern border of the United States. It also requires a national security certification before expeditiously removing any alien and mandates training for Department of Homeland Security employees. Authorization of $10,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2006-2010 to provide comprehensive training for Department of Homeland Security employees on authorized procedures. SEC. 8 amends Section 222(g) of the Immigration and Nationality Act to allow for the cancellation of visas, with exceptions for extraordinary circumstances or technical violations. SEC. 9 addresses the release of aliens from noncontiguous countries. Minimum Bond requirements under Section 236(a)(2) of the Immigration and Nationality Act are amended for nationals of noncontiguous countries who have not been admitted or paroled into the US and were apprehended within 2 years of admission and within 100 miles of the international border or present a flight risk. The Secretary of Homeland Security can allow nationals of noncontiguous countries, who have not been admitted or paroled into the US and were apprehended within 2 years of admission and within 100 miles of the international border, to give a bond of at least $5,000 with approved security. A report on the number of such aliens apprehended must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the effective date of the Act. SEC. 10. REDUCING ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION AND ALIEN SMUGGLING ON TRIBAL LANDS. The Secretary of Homeland Security may award grants to Indian tribes near the US border affected by illegal immigration for law enforcement, health care, environmental restoration, and cultural preservation. A report must be submitted within 180 days on Border Patrol access and immigration law enforcement on tribal lands. Improved immigration laws may involve better access to tribal lands, cooperation with tribal authorities, and grants from the Department of Homeland Security for border security expenses. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2010 for this purpose. SEC. 11. DETENTION SPACE AND REMOVAL CAPACITY amended to increase detention capacity to 10,000 individuals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2006-2010. Legal representation rights for detainees to have reasonable access to legal counsel and notice before any move. SEC. 12. INCREASED CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR ALIEN SMUGGLING, DOCUMENT FRAUD, GANG VIOLENCE, AND DRUG TRAFFICKING. Increased criminal penalties for alien smuggling under the Immigration and Nationality Act, including longer prison sentences and higher fines. Increased criminal penalties for alien smuggling under the Immigration and Nationality Act, including longer prison sentences and higher fines of not less than 3 years nor more than 25 years.
